measured_by: over-reporting solved problems in the matrices task / online matrices task (Mazar et al., 2008)
justification: “Participants were invited to a study about … an online version of the matrices task (Mazar et al., 2008)… In the ‘Fast track’ participants were asked to self-report whether they found the solution or not… Over-reporting of solved problems relative to actual solutions was taken as evidence of cheating.”

“We asked participants to complete several questionnaires used in earlier research to measure the tendency to follow rules: Rule Orientation scale (Fine et al., 2016; 12 items, Cronbach's alpha = 0.921).”
construct: tendency to follow rules / rule orientation

justification: “… Perceived Obligation to Obey the Law (POOL, Tyler, 2006; 6 items, Cronbach's alpha = 0.827)….”
construct: perceived obligation to obey the law

justification: “… General Neutralization Acceptance scale (Esbensen and Osgood, 1999); 9 items, Cronbach's alpha = 0.822….”
construct: neutralization acceptance / acceptance of neutralizing rule violations

justification: “… Mechanisms of Moral Disengagement (Moore et al., 2012; 8 items, Cronbach's alpha = 0.777)….”
“Participants also read four scenarios (from Fine et al., 2016) describing situations with temptations for unethical consumption … We computed average composite scores for … the scenarios.”

measured_by: composite score combining Rule Orientation, Neutralization Acceptance, Moral Disengagement scales and unethical-consumption scenarios
justification: “We computed an overall ‘lawfulness’ score as the sum of the four scales (excluding POOL) and the scenarios' mean scores. Lawfulness ranged from 4–20….”
